features.title: Add references/citations section to generated articles
features.description: Enhance Writer Agent to include properly formatted references section citing sources used in article research. This improves content credibility and provides readers with source attribution.
features.user_story: As a reader, I need to see references and citations for article claims so that I can verify information and explore sources.
acceptance_criteria: All generated articles include 'References' section before closing
References formatted in Economist style (Author, 'Title', Publication, Date)
Research Agent sources automatically included in references
Links to sources include proper anchor text (not 'click here')
Publication Validator blocks articles without references section

content_quality.citation_accuracy: URLs must be functional and match source
content_quality.fact_checking: All statistics must have corresponding reference

accessibility.link_text: Descriptive anchor text, not generic 'click here'
accessibility.screen_reader: References list must be semantic <ol> or <ul>

seo.external_links: Include rel='nofollow' for external sources if policy requires

maintainability.test_coverage: Validator tests for references section presence and format

features.reclassification_reason: This was incorrectly logged as a bug. The requirement for a references section was never specified in the original Writer Agent story. This is a new feature request, not a defect. The system worked as designed - it's the requirements that were incomplete.

requirements_traceability.requirement_note: Original story specified: 'Generate Economist-style articles with proper structure, voice, and data integration.' References section was not explicitly required or forbidden. This is specification evolution, not implementation failure.

implementation_notes: Enhance WRITER_AGENT_PROMPT with references section template
Add Publication Validator check #8 for references presence
Update Blog QA agent to validate reference formatting
Research Agent already collects sources - need to format for output

features.title: Reduce agent idle time via work queue system
features.description: Implement a work queue system to enable parallel agent execution and reduce idle time. Currently, agents run sequentially (Research → Writer → Graphics → Editor), causing significant wait time. A queue-based approach would allow multiple articles to be processed in parallel, with agents pulling work from queues as they become available.
features.user_story: As a system operator, I need agents to process multiple articles in parallel so that we can maximize throughput and reduce total processing time from hours to minutes.
acceptance_criteria: Work queue implementation supports multiple article processing
Agents pull work from queues when available (no idle waiting)
Research Agent outputs feed Writer Agent queue automatically
Writer Agent outputs feed Graphics/Editor queues in parallel
System handles at least 5 concurrent articles without resource exhaustion
Metrics dashboard shows agent utilization rates (target: >80%)
Queue persistence allows recovery from crashes
Dead letter queue handles failed tasks with retry logic

reliability.graceful_degradation: Falls back to sequential on queue failure

maintainability.monitoring: Queue depth, processing times, error rates
maintainability.logging: Trace each article through pipeline stages
maintainability.test_coverage: >90% for queue logic, retry, failure scenarios
maintainability.documentation: Queue architecture diagram, failure recovery guide

security.data_isolation: Article data not leaked across queue workers

implementation_notes: Evaluate queue systems: Celery (heavyweight), RQ (Redis), Python multiprocessing.Queue (lightweight)
Start with Python multiprocessing.Queue for MVP (no external dependencies)
Create QueueOrchestrator class to manage agent workers
Refactor economist_agent.py to separate orchestration from agent logic
Add queue metrics to agent_metrics.py (utilization, wait time, throughput)
Integration tests: parallel processing, crash recovery, retry logic
Performance tests: 5+ concurrent articles, measure throughput improvement
Consider future: distributed queue (Redis) for multi-machine scaling

systems_thinking.current_bottleneck: Sequential agent execution wastes 80% of potential throughput (4 agents x 20% utilization = 80% idle)
systems_thinking.systemic_impact: Enables batch article generation (10 articles in parallel vs 10x sequential time)
systems_thinking.capacity_implications: 5 articles in parallel = 5x throughput improvement (from 1 article/10min to 5 articles/10min)
systems_thinking.risk_mitigation: Start with in-process queues (multiprocessing), scale to Redis if needed
